description.narrative: Support to the Danish Institute for Human Rights through the Danish Arab Partnership Programme 2016.

title.narrative: NCHR has improved the fulfilment of its mandated tasks

Expected outcomes 2016: The National Council for Human Rights (NCHR) has improved the fulfilment of its mandated tasks with focus on human rights monitoring, reporting, and adviceto the government and civil society. Outcome indicators 2016: 1. DIHR and NCHR have implemented activities mentioned in their signed MoU.?2. Civil society organisations have engaged in dialogue with NCHR on their human rights priority issues. 3. NCHR has acquired competencies to work in the area of Human Rights and Business (HRB).

comment.narrative: 1. In 2014, DIHR commenced exchanges with the NCHR with the aim of starting a partnership. 2. Generally, the NCHR lacks human rights expertise and credibility. 3. Human Rights and Business is part of the NCHR mandate; however, it is an underdeveloped field. 4. The Egyptian judiciary has suffered in public legitimacy following the 2011revolution.

title.narrative: The new Libyan constitution sets a framework for establishing a national human rights system in Libya

Outcome indicator: 1. If (re-)established, the NCCLHR and/or a governmental human rights focal point has/have taken steps towards promoting and protecting human rights in Libya. 2. The draft constitutional text prepared by the CDA enshrines basic human rights. 3. Local level governance structures – e.g. local councils – are involved in the work of both the CDA and the NCCLHR in order to define and strengthen the role of local governance in the Libyan national human rights system.

comment.narrative:
1. In 2014, the National Council for Civil Liberties and Human Rights (NCCLHR) had to close due to the breakout of hostilities. It has remained closed in Tripoli and Benghazi since then.
2. In 2014, the Constituent Drafting Assembly (CDA) was established and started work on a draft constitution.
3. With the support of the former NCCLHR, and contacts established through the Merit Network for Democracy and the Rule of Law (MNDRL), DIHR established a dialogue with the the CDA Committee on Rights, Freedoms and Transitional Measures.
4. The MNDRL carries out a limited number of activities due to the security situation. Focus is on retaining a core group of active members.

title.narrative: The national human rights system in Tunisia has been strengthened and consolidated

Outcome indicators: 1. A new human rights instance has taken steps towards performing in accordance with the UN Paris Principles.? 2. The Minister for Relations with Constitutional Bodies, Civil Society and Human Rights has taken active steps to promote and protect human rights in Tunisia. 3. The government has submitted reports to the UN treaty bodies.

comment.narrative: 1. The MJHRTJ published a strategic plan for the human rights services in Tunisia in 2014. 2. The 2014 Constitution outlines a new human rights instance. 3. In 2014, the MJHRTJ carried out the initial work on the legislative frameworks for a new human rights instance and an inter-ministerial human rights reporting mechanism. 4. In 2015, the Minister Delegate to the Prime Minister for Relations with Constitutional Bodies and Civil Society replaced the MJHRTJ as a governmental human rights focal point. 5. In 2016, the Minister Delegate became the Minister for Relations with Constitutional Bodies, Civil Society and Human Rights.

title.narrative: Human rights based dialogue and exchange deepens the understanding of, and promotion and protection of human rights both across the Middle East and North Africa and in Denmark.

1. DIHR and partners have actively exchanged knowledge and experience related to the promotion, protection and respect of human rights. 2. NHRIs in the Middle East and North Africa have engaged in networking and knowledge sharing. 3. DIHR has contributed to human rights dialogue activities initiated by actors in the Middle East and North Africa. 4. The Danish public and media have had focus on the human rights situation in the Middle East and North Africa due to DIHR activities.

comment.narrative: 1. The third regional human rights course was held in Nabeul, Tunisia. 2. DIHR launched the Copenhagen Debates with an event entitled ‘Revolution or Reform’ at the National Library, Copenhagen, Denmark. 3. Two researchers from Egypt and Iran visited DIHR. 4. Co-operation with the European Inter-University Centre commenced, which opened the possibility of creating a regional MA in democracy and human rights. 5. No formalised mechanism for the exchange of staff between NHRIs in the Middle East and North Africa was in place in 2014.

title.narrative: NCHR have improved the fulfilment of its mandated tasks

1. DIHR and NCHR have consolidated and further rolled out collaboration through joint activities and capacity development. 2. As part of the human rights system of Egypt, NCHR has played a role to ensure that Egypt progressively meets its human rights obligations. 3. DIHR has started engagements with the Egyptian judiciary focused on strengthening its role in the national human rights system.
The new Libyan constitution sets a framework for establishing a national human rights system in Libya
The NCCLHR and/or governmental human rights focal point has/have started to function as an actor(s) of the Libyan national human rights system, and the CDA has prepared a draft constitutional text.
The national human rights system in Tunisia has been strengthened and consolidated

1. The independent human rights instance has been established and is able to function in accordance with its mandate. 2. The governmental human rights focal point coordinates the increased promotion and protection of human rights in Tunisia. 3. The inter-ministerial human rights mechanism has coordinated and drafted at least one treaty body report for submission to the UN.
Human rights based dialogue and exchange deepens the understanding of, and promotion and protection of human rights both across the Middle East and North Africa and in Denmark.

1. A MENA human rights expert carries out a small-scale research projects at DIHR. 2. Debates on human rights in the Middle East and North Africa are organised for Danish organisations, experts and the public in Denmark. 3. At least one staff from a NHRI in the Middle East and North Africa has been part of a DIHR facilitated staff exchange between NHRIs. 4. A second cohort of students graduate from the DIHR supported DE.MA (MA on Democratic Governance and Human Rights in the Middle East and North Africa).
